passages.text: CFO Follow- Up Takes & Model Matt= Buying Opportunity; Overweight
4 Key Incremental CFO Follow- Up Takeaways:

(1) July Comp Inflection To Close 2Q ... Breaking down the cadence of 2Q's \(+1.0\%\) comp growth, CFO O'Connell noted May/June started slow due to unfavorably cold/wet weather weighing on core seasonal merchandise ( \(\sim\) Flat May/June consolidated SSS by our work), relative to a sharp acceleration to mid-single-digit comps in July on our estimates, coinciding w the Fall product drop and back-to-school assortment flowed through to stores. By brand, 2Q same-store-sales growth of \(+1.0\%\) (vs. Street \(+1.9\) ) included in-line results across Gap \(+4\%\) & Old Navy \(+2\%\) relative to Consensus, outperformance at Banana Republic \(+4\%\) ( \(>\) Street \(+0.8\%\) ), and underperformance at Athleta \(-9\%\) ( \(Adj. EPS - 26E ($)PrevCur 2.162.31

P/E9.810.59.48.0

We rate GAP Overweight. With the foundation set under CEO Dickson to support a consistent playbook of improved merchandising & marketing across all four brands, we see GAP at an inflection point to support +low- to- mid- single- digit sales growth, annual operating margin expansion targeting historical levels of profitability (i.e. \(8 - 10\%\) ) led by SG&A leverage (w/ efficiencies more than offsetting continued "strategic reinvestments") and modest gross margin expansion driven by ROD leverage (at less than \(1\%\) revenue growth post \(\sim 800\) store closures since pre- pandemic), with capital allocation (i.e. \(\) 650M\(annual net FCF) adding \(\sim 4\%\) accretion from share repurchase equating to a total EPS growth profile of \(+14\%\) or mid- to- high- teens total- shareholder- return profile.
We raise our Dec '26 Price Target to \(\) 32\((vs.\) \ \(29\) prior) based on 5.3x our FY27 EBITDA, commensurate with GAP's 3/5- yr prepandemic average multiple.

(3) FY25 Margin Outlook = Tariff Trough FY26+ Expansion Opportunity: Relative to a \(\sim 100 - 110\) bps net headwind anticipated within FY25's operating margin outlook from the current trade policy (inclusive of India \(\sim 50\%\) rates), CFO O'Connell stated "we do not currently expect the annualization of tariffs in 2026 to cause further operating income declines next year and we expect to mitigate the full impact of tariffs over-time, which we believe represents opportunity for operating margin improvement longer-term." Specifically, CFO O'Connell confirmed in our callback that tariffs are expected to be a neutral impact to FY26 operating margins (vs. net headwind in FY25) as a result of improved mitigation efforts across an increasingly diversified sourcing mix, negotiations with vendor partners post final details in August, product/assortment mix changes, and greater full price selling with FY25's 6.7-7.0% operating margin confirmed as the "floor". Taking this a step further, CFO O'Connell reaffirmed the company's top/bottom-line economic model of operating margin expansion (inclusive of modest GPM expansion & SG&A leverage) anticipated at +low-single-digit revenue growth given the current fixed cost structure - pointing to FY26 operating margin expansion YOY opportunity (above Street EBIT margins down 10bps YOY).

- Importantly, management also cited no constraints to fully mitigating tariff headwinds over-time (i.e. \(2025^{\circ}\) s \(\sim 100 - 110\) bps drag implied on current rates will prove "transitory" over-time) - pointing to an underlying operating margin rate of the business in FY25 at 7.7-8.0% (vs. the 6.7-7.0% outlook) - with CFO O'Connell noting a track record of identifying cost efficiencies & diversifying the supply chain (with China planned to reduce to 3% of sourcing exiting 2025 vs \(\sim 10\%\) in 2024 & 21% in 2019). Said differently, the "transitory" 100-110bps operating margin headwind from tariffs included within FY25's P/L represents \(\sim 50.30\) of EPS power - pointing to "fundamental" EPS power in FY25 of \(\sim \$ 2.40\) & \(\sim \$ 2.60\) in FY26 (= 21% upside relative to Consensus FY26 EPS of \(\$ 2.14\) ).

(4) Breaking Down Near-Term Margin Puts/Takes: GAP 2Q25 GPM contracted -140bps Y/Y to 41.2% (below Street 42.0%) driven by (i) 150bps of merchandise margin contraction, lapping the y/y benefit of incremental sales from the company's revenue sharing agreement w/ its credit card provider, in addition to markdown pressure associated with a deliberate clearing of inventory at Athleta given the brand's topline underperformance offset by (ii) 10bps of favorable ROD leverage on the +1.0% comp. Looking ahead, management guided 3Q gross margins to decline 150bps to 170bps Y/Y (vs. Street -150bps) w/mgmt quantifying a net tariff related cost headwind of \(\sim 200\) bps partially offset by anticipated ROD leverage at \(+2\%\) revenue growth & slight favorability on AURs/markdowns (led by Gap). On expenses, 2Q SG&A leveraged 130bps to 33.4% (vs. Street 34.5%) tied to disciplined cost savings, with management guiding 3Q SG&A to slightly deleverage Y/Y as timing of certain expenses shifted from 2Q into 3Q.

Model Implications: We model FY25 EPS of \(\) 2.07\(vs. Street\) \ \(2.09\) ) & raise FY26 EPS to \(\) 2.31\(vs. Street\) \ \(2.38\) ). Remain Overweight raising our Dec '26 Price Target to \(\) 32\(vs. \)\\(29\) prior) based on \(\sim 5.3x\) our FY27 EBITDA supported by our linear regression analysis relative to GAP's pre- pandemic top/bottom- line growth profile.

- The 2Q Print: GAP reported 2Q EPS of \(\) 0.57\(vs. Street\) \ \(0.55\) ) based on in-line \(+0.1\%\) revenue growth (vs. mgmt's Flat sales outlook) and -Flat operating margins Y/Y to 7.8% (\(>\) Street 7.5%) with -140bps gross margin contraction to 41.2% (below Street 42.0%) offset by favorable SG&A leverage of 130bps Y/Y to 33.4% of sales (vs. Street 34.5%).- FY25 Guide: Looking ahead, management reaffirmed FY25's \(+1 - 2\%\) revenue growth outlook (vs. Street \(+1.6\%\) ) & outlined operating margin expectations of 6.7-7.0% (= Street 6.9% & JPM e 7.0%) despite raising the net tariff headwind to \(\sim 100 - 110\) bps (vs. \(\sim 65 - 100\) bps prior) equating to EPS of \(\) 2.00-\$ 2.10 (vs. Street \(\) 2.09\$ ). Near-term, management guided 3Q sales growth to \(+1.5 - 2.5\%\) Y/Y (vs. Street \(+1.9\%\) ), gross

margin decline of 150- 170bps Y/Y (vs. Street - 150bps) inclusive of a \(\sim 200\) bps tariff headwind, and slight SG&A deleverage ( \(\sim 20 - 30\) bps by our work), equating to 3Q EPS of \(\sim \$ 0.57\) (vs. Street \$0.63) on our math.

- Balance Sheet Snapshot: GAP ended 2Q with cash, cash equivalents, and short-term investments of \$2.2B (1Q 2.2B) vs. long-term debt of \$1.5B (1Q 1.5B). Inventory ended the quarter up \(+9\%\) Y/Y (vs. 1Q \(+7\%\) Y/Y) primarily reflecting earlier timing of receipts. On shareholder returns, GAP paid a dividend of \$0.165/share and repurchased 3M shares for \$82M in 2Q with \(\sim \$ 250M\) remaining under the share purchase authorization. On capital plans, management continues to see FY25 capex of \(\sim \$ 500-\) 550M (vs.600M prior) invest in organic opportunities for value creation.

The Gap, Inc. (Overweight; Price Target: \(32.00)

We rate GAP Overweight. With the foundation set under CEO Dickson to support a consistent playbook of improved merchandising & marketing across all four brands, we see GAP at an inflection point to support +low- to- mid- single- digit sales growth, annual operating margin expansion targeting historical levels of profitability (i.e. \(8 - 10\%\) ) led by SG&A leverage (w/ efficiencies more than offsetting continued "strategic reinvestments") and modest gross margin expansion driven by ROD leverage (at less than \(1\%\) revenue growth post \(\sim 800\) store closures since pre- pandemic), with capital allocation (i.e. \(\) 650M\(annual net FCF) adding - 4\%\) accretion from share repurchase equating to a total EPS growth profile of \(+14\%\) or mid- to- high- teens total- shareholder- return profile.
We raise our Dec '26 Price Target to \(32 (vs. \$29\) prior) based on 5.3x our FY27 EBITDA, commensurate with GAP's 3/5- yr pre- pandemic average multiple.

J.P. Morgan uses the following rating system: Overweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will outperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); Neutral (over the duration of the price target indicated in this report, we expect this stock will perform in line with the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe); and Underweight (over the duration of the price target indicated in

this report, we expect this stock will underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating and, if applicable, the price target, for this stock because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating and, if applicable, the price target, no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. In Americas equity research, some stocks under coverage have a rating but no price target; in these cases, we expect the stock will outperform/perform in line/underperform the average total return of the stocks in the Research Analyst's, or the Research Analyst's team's, coverage universe over the next six to 12 months. In our Asia (ex-Australia and ex-India) and U.K. small- and mid-cap Equity Research, each stock's expected total return is compared to the expected total return of a benchmark country market index, not to those Research Analysts' coverage universe. If it does not appear in the Important Disclosures section of this report, the certifying Research Analyst's coverage universe can be found on J.P. Morgan's Research website, https://www.jpmorganmarkets.com.
